content.value: Linux defines who can read, write, or execute a file or directory.
content.example: Example: Allowing only the owner to edit a file while others can only read it.

content.value: Linux is a multi-user operating system. File permissions protect files from unauthorized access, accidental deletion, and security threats.
Every file in Linux has an owner and a group that control access to the file.
content.example: Example: A file owned by user john and group developers.

content.value: Linux divides ownership into three categories: owner, group, and others.
File permissions define what actions users can perform on a file or directory.
content.example: Example: Read, write, or execute access.

content.value: You can view file permissions using the ls -l command.
